detaileddescription.para:
e
Exception object to throw.
Using this macro instead of throw directly makes it possible to uniformly attach information into the exception objects. e should evaluate to an instance of an object derived from GromacsException.

memberdef.name: GMX_THROW_WITH_ERRNO
memberdef.initializer: do { \ int stored_errno_ = (err); \ GMX_THROW((e) << gmx::ExceptionInfoErrno(stored_errno_) \ << gmx::ExceptionInfoApiFunction(syscall)); \ } while (0)

briefdescription.para: Macro for throwing an exception based on errno.

detaileddescription.para:
e
Exception object to throw.
syscall
Name of the syscall that returned the error.
err
errno value returned by the syscall.
This macro provides a convenience interface for throwing an exception to report an error based on a errno value. In addition to adding the necessary information to the exception object, the macro also ensures that errno is evaluated before, e.g., the constructor of e may call other functions that could overwrite the errno value. e should evaluate to an instance of an object derived from GromacsException.

briefdescription.para: Macro for catching exceptions at C++ -> C boundary.

detaileddescription.para: This macro is intended for uniform handling of exceptions when C++ code is called from C code within Gromacs. Since most existing code is written using the assumption that fatal errors terminate the program, this macro implements this behavior for exceptions. It should only be used in cases where the error cannot be propagated upwards using return values or such.
Having this as a macro instead of having the same code in each place makes it easy to 1) find all such locations in the code, and 2) change the exact behavior if needed.

briefdescription.para: Declares common exception classes and macros for fatal error handling.

detaileddescription.para: The basic approach is the same as in boost::exception for storing additional context information to exceptions, but since that functionality is a very small and simple part of boost::exception, the code is duplicated here.
